author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Watch This Summery, Soapy New Drama Starring Nicole Kidman
description: Looking for something to watch this week? Our critic recommends “Nine Perfect Strangers” a lush new David E. Kelley adaptation of a book by Liane Moriarty.
content: This is a preview of the Watching newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox four times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Disaster in Afghanistan Will Follow Us Home
description: Biden owns the moment. He’ll also own the consequences.
content: What on earth was Joe Biden thinking — if, that is, he was thinking?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: All health care workers in New York must get vaccinated, the governor says.
description: The mandate will apply to all hospitals, nursing homes and adult care facilities, public and private.
content: Issuing a major directive in his last weeks in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said Monday that all health care workers in the state, including staff at all hospitals, nursing homes, adult care facilities and other congregate care settings, must get at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine by Sept. 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Beard Crusader
description: Brigham Young has banned most types of facial hair for decades. One emeritus professor at the university is leading the charge to change that.
content: At Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, beards have been banned on campus since the rise of the counterculture movement, when they were thought to be associated with hippies and antiwar sentiments many young people expressed in the 1960s and ’70s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Guarding the Last Likeness of a Loathed Dictator? It’s a Thankless Job.
description: The image of Enver Hoxha, a feared tyrant, was once everywhere in Albania. His last intact statue is watched over by a partly blind, 80-year-old defender. “Nobody wants him anymore.”
content: LABINOT MAL, Albania — Swaddled in straw on the dirt floor of a stable, the once omnipotent dictator lies helpless on his back. His face specked with bird droppings, he stares blankly at the sagging roof, a final indignity for a leader whose all-seeing eyes held millions in terrified thrall for four decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Spiedie Sauce Is Just the Beginning
description: Taste NY, run by New York’s agriculture department, sells foods made in the Empire State online, and it ships nationwide.
content: Taste NY, created by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets and the governor’s office in 2013 to promote locally made food products, has made the foods and other local items available online. The digital marketplace is run by the Cornell Cooperative Extension of Sullivan County. The products, like pickles, jams, condiments, sauces, syrups and the like, are sorted by region. They’re the same products that are sold at many official state stores throughout New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: How a ’00s College Debate Team Predicted Today’s Culture Wars
description: The rise of the Malcolm X Debate Society.
content: This is a preview of the Jay Caspian Kang newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Lawmakers Unite in Bipartisan Fury Over Afghanistan Withdrawal
description: If President Biden hoped to find cover from politicians in both parties who had reached a broad consensus on withdrawal, he was most likely disappointed.
content: President Biden’s unapologetic defense on Monday of his decisions in Afghanistan rallied some Democrats to his side, but the president still faces angry and increasingly public criticism from lawmakers in both parties over the chaos descending on Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: He Is a Journalist With Autism, but in His Book, That’s Not the Whole Story
description: Eric Garcia, the author of “We’re Not Broken,” talks about public policy’s role in caring for autistic people, his reportorial instincts and more.
content: The political journalist Eric Garcia has autism, and he wrote his new book, “We’re Not Broken,” to “hopefully debunk various myths” about the condition. In his introduction, he notes that there are many such myths: that autism only affects white males; that there’s a connection between autism and violent behavior; that those with autism are only capable of holding jobs in technology; that they can’t have relationships or live independently. Though there are elements of memoir in the book, Garcia says his experience is just one small detail in a much larger picture of a wide variety of people who suffer in “a world that penalizes them for not playing by its rules.” Below, Garcia talks about the profound importance of public policy, his reportorial instincts, the soundtrack to his writing and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: After Backlash, Lawmakers Will Issue Report on Cuomo Impeachment Inquiry
description: In a reversal, the New York State Assembly said it would continue its investigation of Gov. Andrew Cuomo. That does not mean lawmakers will move to impeach him.
content: Reversing course, the New York State Assembly will continue its broad investigation of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and issue a report with its findings, lawmakers said on Monday, following fierce bipartisan backlash over the decision to suspend the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: Health Care Workers in New York Must Get Vaccine, Cuomo Says
description: In his first major policy announcement since saying he would resign, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said New York health care workers must be vaccinated by Sept. 27.
content: Issuing a major directive in his last days in office, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that all health care workers in the state, including staff at hospitals, nursing homes, adult care facilities and other congregate care settings, must get at least one dose of coronavirus vaccine by Sept. 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Master the Art of the Japanese Cocktail
description: Masahiro Urushido and Michael Anstendig’s “The Japanese Art of the Cocktail” explores, through recipes, what makes the drinks so special.
content: The cover of “The Japanese Art of the Cocktail” gives you some idea of what making cocktails the Japanese way involves. It shows one of the authors, Masahiro Urushido, using a pick to sculpt a large ball of ice. The big, clear ice cube, usually made from molds these days, is a signature that the Japanese cocktail culture has brought to cocktails in the United States and elsewhere. Mr. Urushido, an owner of Katana Kitten, a bar in the West Village, details the precise approach the Japanese take, not just to carving the ice, but to assemble drinks. He describes his career, from low-rung beginnings as a food runner to a sought-after mixologist in Japan and New York. The book explains high-end cocktail bars in Japan and more informal izakayas; his bar blends both. Many of the book’s recipes, with long drinks and Japanese riffs on classics, are demanding; some simpler examples are the Japanese highball using frozen whiskey; the Far East Side with sake, tequila and shiso leaves; and Friday in the Park combining pear cider and vermouth (though he recommends making your own vermouth). The book, released in June, has a guide to ingredients and sources.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: In Zambia Election, Opposition Leader Storms to Decisive Win Over President
description: Voters picked Hakainde Hichilema, a businessman who had lost five previous bids for the job, to take over from Edgar Lungu, who has led the southern African nation since 2015.
content: JOHANNESBURG — The leader of Zambia’s main opposition party sailed to victory in the nation’s presidential election, according to results announced on Monday, staving off strong-arm tactics from the incumbent governing party that had stoked fears of a rigged vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Tribes’ Victory in Oklahoma at Risk in Bold Request to the Supreme Court
description: Last year, the court ruled 5 to 4 that much of the state is an Indian reservation. Oklahoma wants a do-over, testing the court’s respect for the power of precedent.
content: WASHINGTON — The precedent, which ruled that much of eastern Oklahoma falls within an Indian reservation, is just over a year old. A couple of weeks ago, Oklahoma asked the Supreme Court to overrule it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Nonalcoholic Rosé Worth Meeting
description: Wölffer Estate’s Spring in a Bottle is a rich and tart alcohol-free wine.
content: Making satisfying nonalcoholic wine appears to be a greater challenge than producing good wine with alcohol. A winner in this rapidly growing category is the new sparkling nonalcoholic rosé, Spring in a Bottle, that Wölffer Estate in Sagaponack, N.Y., introduced last month. It’s made in Germany from organic pinot noir, merlot and St. Laurent grapes in partnership with the Strauch Distillery in Rheinhessen. The pink wine, with nice carbonation and a delicately floral bouquet has the flavor of white peaches: rich, tart, nicely fruity but not sweet. Wine drinkers will not miss the alcohol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: An Iconic Bridge Sees U.S. Allies Flee Afghanistan as the Soviets Did
description: Retreating Afghan government soldiers crowded onto a bridge over the Amu Darya River that was a backdrop for the Soviet failure in Afghanistan decades ago.
content: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan — The bridge has an eerily Orwellian name — the Friendship Bridge — and a storied history in Afghanistan’s wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Kudo
title: I Was a Marine in Afghanistan. We Sacrificed Lives For a Lie.
description: Those of us who fought this war must now wonder: How could we have given the best parts of our lives to such a lie?
content: The Afghan cities fall in rapid succession, like men caught in enfilade fire. First Zaranj, Kunduz a few days later, then Kandahar and Lashkar Gah. Next is Mazar-i-Sharif. And finally, the Taliban begin their move to swiftly and decisively take Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins and Benjamin Mueller
title: Covid Vaccines Produced in Africa Are Being Exported to Europe
description: Johnson & Johnson is sending shots from South Africa to other parts of the world. African countries are waiting for most of the doses they’ve ordered.
content: Johnson & Johnson’s Covid vaccine was supposed to be one of Africa’s most important weapons against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen Gets a Chance to Shape the Fed, This Time From Outside
description: As Jerome H. Powell nears the end of his term as Federal Reserve chair, Ms. Yellen will have a say over whether he should stay on. Many progressive Democrats want him replaced.
content: Janet L. Yellen has dedicated most of her professional life to the Federal Reserve. She served in its highest-ranking roles, including as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, on its Washington-based board and as the central bank’s first female chair. When President Donald J. Trump decided to replace her in that role in 2017, she was sorely disappointed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca J. Ritzel
title: Theater Director With Exaggerated Résumé Quits, Citing Mental Illness
description: Christopher Massimine found success as a theater executive in New hYork and Utah, but resigned after facing questions about errors on his résumé, saying he had mental illness.
content: Christopher Massimine, whose job as the managing director of the Pioneer Theater Company in Salt Lake City was thrown into doubt after a local television affiliate found that he had embellished his résumé with untrue claims, announced Monday that he would resign his post and said that he had long struggled with mental illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Golf Carts Are Parked, Walking Is In and, Yes, It’s Exercise
description: Motorized carts have ferried golfers from hole to hole for 50 years, but more players these days are walking their rounds, and some courses have shunned carts entirely.
content: There is a new movement afoot in recreational golf: walking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Billie Eilish Holds at No. 1, Bolstered Again by Physical Sales
description: George Harrison’s 1970 triple album “All Things Must Pass” also returns to the Top 10 for the first time in 50 years thanks to a host of reissues.
content: It may be a digital world, but when it comes to the weekly music charts, old-fashioned sales still make a big difference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Bad Economics of Fossil Fuel Defenders
description: Why you should ignore claims that we can't afford to reduce emissions.
content: Global warming is fake news. Anyway, it isn’t man-made. And doing anything about it would destroy the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Record Rise in Food Stamp Aid Aims to Stem Hunger’s Spread
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 15, 2021
content: “Within two weeks it was gone. I never had to worry about it before. We always had food.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Flights resume at Kabul’s airport after security breach.
description: Troops had been working to secure the airport on Monday after halting flights because of security concerns on the civilian side, officials said.
content: U.S. military planes resumed flying into Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul on Monday evening after a pause earlier in the day while troops worked to secure the airport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Alex Ingram
title: What a U.K. Staycation Looks Like in a Pandemic
description: The classic summer holiday to Europe has been replaced by a trip to the shores of England, where business is good but owners struggle with worker shortages and Covid restrictions.
content: ISLE OF WIGHT, England — For the second year running, a hallowed rite for millions of people in Britain — decamping to the warmer climate of the Mediterranean — has been disrupted by the pandemic. The number of flights in and out of Britain are half their 2019 levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Hachette to Buy Workman for $240 Million as Publishing Continues Consolidation
description: Workman, known for “What to Expect When You’re Expecting” and other lucrative older titles, is one of the largest independent publishers in the United States.
content: Hachette Book Group said on Monday that it had agreed to buy Workman Publishing, an independent company known for titles like “What to Expect When You’re Expecting” and the “Brain Quest” workbooks, the latest expected acquisition in an industry whose power is increasingly concentrated in a handful of major companies. The cost of the deal was $240 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Sidle Up to This Bar for an Herbal Infusion
description: The Alchemist’s Kitchen in SoHo has added the Elixir Bar next door, selling herbs meant to affect the mood.
content: Herbal mixtures, which some consider to be remedies, date back to the very mists of civilization. Lou Sagar, who was a lifestyle and wellness consultant, founded the Alchemist’s Kitchen in SoHo in 2017 as a place to sell herbal products and give advice about them. As natural remedies have grown in popularity, Mr. Sagar has now added the Elixir Bar next door, where herbal mixtures said to affect the mood are served and sold. The elixirs can be added to sparkling water, teas, coffees, kombucha, milks and very pretty infusions; consumed as plain shots and mocktails; and bottled to take home. Gluten-free vegan snacks like banana bread, muffins, cookies and quiches are served. The bright white store, with vintage touches, has a small bar and a communal table. Mr. Sagar said he vetted his sources for botanicals very carefully; on the company’s website there’s an excellent disclaimer about the efficacy of herbal remedies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Getting Soccer Fans Into Art? That’s the Goal.
description: A new gallery at the stadium of Tottenham Hotspur, a top London club, is presenting contemporary works to visitors, with mixed results.
content: LONDON — Annie Lawrence, 8, was looking excited on Sunday afternoon. She was about to see Tottenham Hotspur, the soccer team she supports, play its first game of the English Premier League season — but her exhilaration wasn’t entirely because of the impending game.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Full Transcript of President Biden’s Remarks on Afghanistan
description: Mr. Biden spoke from the White House on Monday afternoon after the collapse of the Afghan government to the Taliban.
content: The following is a transcript of President Biden’s remarks on Monday about the U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Joe Walton, Giants Star Who Found Futility as Jets Coach, Dies at 85
description: He took them to the playoffs several times in the 1980s but was dismissed after a 53-57 record. He went on to achieve success as a college coach.
content: Joe Walton, who as a player helped take the Giants to three consecutive N.F.L. championship games in the early 1960s with his outstanding pass-catching and blocking, but who found considerably less success coaching the N.F.L.’s other New York team, the Jets, for most of the 1980s, died on Sunday in Englewood, Fla. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Stand Up to Cancer’ and ‘Nora From Queens’
description: Common, Stevie Wonder and Brittany Howard are slated to perform at a fund-raiser for cancer research. And Awkwafina’s Comedy Central sitcom returns.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 16-22. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Deaths in custody of two brothers fuel anger over Covid enforcement in Kenya.
description: Benson and Emmanuel Ndwiga died of head and rib injuries after being detained on suspicion of breaching a curfew. The case has thrown a fresh spotlight on police brutality in the country.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Scrutiny of police enforcement of coronavirus rules in Kenya has gained urgency after the deaths in custody of two brothers who were detained on suspicion of breaking a curfew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Man Pleads Guilty to Threatening to Kill Newly Elected U.S. Senator
description: Federal prosecutors said Eduard Florea of Queens posted menacing threats online against Raphael Warnock of Georgia and Congress before and during the storming of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: A New York man who supported the far-right Proud Boys group pleaded guilty on Monday to threatening to kill Raphael Warnock, a newly elected senator from Georgia, before and during the Jan. 6 storming of the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg and Adam Nossiter
title: After 7 Years of Failing to Fix Afghanistan, Ghani Makes a Hasty Escape
description: By the time ex-president Ashraf Ghani fled the country, the hot-tempered leader was isolated and ineffective. Critics blamed him for the chaos in Kabul, saying he had betrayed his people.
content: Western technocrat. Would-be populist. Wartime president. Ashraf Ghani tried to inhabit many roles during his years as Afghanistan’s president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsea Garrison, Annie Brown, Rachelle Bonja, Stella Tan, Larissa Anderson, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Fall of Afghanistan
description: One Kabul resident recounts her experiences as the Taliban seized the capital and chaos descended.
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Ruhullah Khapalwak
title: Chaos Ensues at Kabul Airport as Americans Abandon Afghanistan
description: Images of desperate Afghans clinging to departing military planes underscored America’s blunders after 20 years in the country.
content: ISTANBUL — Thousands of desperate Afghans trying to escape the Taliban takeover swarmed Kabul’s main international airport on Monday, rushing the boarding gates, mobbing the runways, clambering atop the wings of jets and even trying to cling to the fuselage of departing American military planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Georgia will increase hospital funding amid a Covid surge.
description: The governor on Monday also announced a day off for state workers, encouraging them to use the time to get vaccinated.
content: With coronavirus cases surging across Georgia, Gov. Brian Kemp on Monday announced plans to spend more than $125 million to add staff and increase capacity at hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Perfect Clam for Your Pasta Sauce
description: The Lobster Place in Chelsea Market now carries butter clams, farmed in Maine, at a size just right for pasta alle vongole.
content: When Atlantic surf clams, the mollusks with the big white shells you see empty on the beaches from Cape Hatteras, N.C., to Canada, are very small, no more than two inches across, they’re called butter clams or petite surf clams. They’re being farmed in Maine and on Cape Cod. Smaller and more tender than littlenecks, they are the ideal clam for spaghetti or linguine alle vongole, pasta with clam sauce. Now the Lobster Place in Chelsea Market has started to get shipments of these sweet little clams. The market expects to have them on a regular basis starting this week, but Brendan Hayes, the president, said they rely on an oyster supplier in Maine, and should have a delivery every week through Labor Day. They’re worth seeking out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Biden Could Still Be Proved Right in Afghanistan
description: It is hard to imagine a worse morning after for the Biden team in Kabul. But everything really important happens the morning after the morning after.
content: For years, U.S. officials used a shorthand phrase to describe America’s mission in Afghanistan. It always bothered me: We are there to train the Afghan Army to fight for its own government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Naomi Osaka Struggles in Return to Tournament News Conferences
description: Osaka, who quit the French Open in May by saying press commitments worsened her anxiety, burst into tears and left the room after a question her agent said was asked “to intimidate.”
content: Naomi Osaka’s return to the news conference format after a three-month hiatus went smoothly for three questions on Monday ahead of the Western & Southern Open in Mason, Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Jake Lacy Says Aloha to ‘The White Lotus’
description: In an interview, the actor discusses the HBO social satire, Sunday’s season finale and the possibility of his returning for Season 2.
content: This interview includes spoilers for Sunday’s season finale of “The White Lotus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette and Niraj Chokshi
title: U.S. Will Investigate Tesla’s Autopilot System Over Crashes With Emergency Vehicles
description: It will be the broadest look yet at Tesla’s assisted-driving technology. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has the authority to force a recall or require new safety features.
content: The U.S. auto safety regulator said Monday that it had opened a broad investigation of the Autopilot system used in hundreds of thousands of Tesla’s electric cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Living With O.C.D. in a Pandemic
description: Covid made things worse for many people with obsessive-compulsive disorder. But it also came with a silver lining.
content: Most people behave in one or more ways that others may consider peculiar, and I am no exception. I want my clothes to match, from shoes to eyeglasses and everything in between (including underwear — a challenge when packing for a trip). If visitors use my kitchen, they’re asked to put things back exactly where they were found. In arranging my furniture, countertops and wall-hangings, I strive for symmetry. And I label packaged foods with their expiration dates and place them in my pantry in date order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Dan Levin
title: Tennessee’s governor allows parents to opt out of mask mandates at school.
description: His order says that parents or guardians “shall have the right to opt out of any order or requirement” that their children wear face coverings.
content: As the Delta variant fuels a new coronavirus wave, particularly in areas with underwhelming vaccination rates, Tennessee on Monday became the latest state where a governor has undermined efforts by local school districts to require students to wear masks as the new school year approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: Covert Actions: How Espionage Has Helped Win Wars
description: Four new books examine some of the darker corners of World War II and the Cold War.
content: Books about espionage are in a class by themselves, sometimes illuminating but often raising more questions than they answer, as a crop of new works reminds us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: On an iconic bridge, U.S. allies flee Afghanistan as the Soviets did.
description: In a chaotic retreat from the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif in recent days, pro-government soldiers streamed onto the Friendship Bridge, seeking safety on the other bank in neighboring Uzbekistan.
content: In a chaotic retreat from the northern Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif in recent days, pro-government soldiers streamed onto the Friendship Bridge, seeking safety on the other bank in neighboring Uzbekistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis, Christiaan Triebert, Evan Hill, Brenna Smith and Dmitriy Khavin
title: What Scenes From the Taliban’s Victory in Afghanistan Reveal
description: The fall of Afghanistan’s government was captured in hundreds of videos from across the country. We analyzed some of the key moments.
content: The Taliban seized power in Afghanistan on Sunday after a rapid advance across the country, overwhelming government forces and sending large swaths of the population into panic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Katie Glueck
title: Becoming the Un-Cuomo: Kathy Hochul’s Rise to the Governorship
description: A western New Yorker with centrist Democratic roots, she is described as both tough and disarming. She is also relatively untested.
content: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo barreled into the 2018 primary season, buffeted by criticisms from the increasingly powerful left wing of the Democratic Party, his team privately worried that he needed a more progressive running mate or a person of color with deeper ties downstate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Culture Change and Conflict at Twitter
description: Two years ago, the company brought in a blunt executive to make things move faster and to promote diversity. Then the problems began.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Soon after joining Twitter in 2019, Dantley Davis gathered his staff in a conference room at the company’s San Francisco headquarters. Twitter was too nice, he told the group, and he was there to change it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 16, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 16, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: New York City Mandates Vaccines for Museum Visitors and Staff
description: The mayor and cultural institutions agree to require vaccinations as coronavirus cases rise with the spread of the Delta variant.
content: New York City plans to require visitors and staff members at museums and other cultural institutions to be vaccinated, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Thousands Who Helped the U.S. in Afghanistan Are Trapped. What Happens Next?
description: Many of those who worked alongside U.S. troops have waited years for visas to come to the United States. The speedy withdrawal of forces left most of them behind.
content: Tens of thousands of Afghan nationals risked their lives to assist the United States military in Afghanistan, many of them working as interpreters alongside American soldiers in combat. Now, after the Taliban’s takeover, they are more desperate than ever to leave — but swift, safe passage to the United States may prove elusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Are Robotic Surgeries Really Better?
description: Robot-assisted surgeries have only modest advantages over other approaches, a large analysis found.
content: Surgical procedures performed with the aid of a robot is sometimes marketed as the “best” form of surgery. But a recent review of 50 randomized controlled trials, testing robot-assisted surgeries against conventional methods for abdominal or pelvic procedures, suggests that while there may be some benefits to robotic surgery, any advantages over other approaches are modest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Museum of Broadway in Times Square Sets New Opening Date
description: The first institution dedicated to the history of the Great White Way and the artistry of its shows and theaters plans to welcome visitors next summer.
content: After multiple delays, the first museum dedicated to telling the storied history of Broadway shows is now expected to open its doors next summer in the heart of the theater district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: In a First, U.S. Declares Shortage on Colorado River, Forcing Water Cuts
description: Arizona farmers will take the initial brunt, but wider reductions loom as climate change continues to affect flows into the river.
content: With climate change and long-term drought continuing to take a toll on the Colorado River, the federal government on Monday for the first time declared a water shortage at Lake Mead, one of the river’s main reservoirs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Henri Forms in the Atlantic
description: The storm, the eighth of the Atlantic hurricane season, joins Tropical Storm Fred and Tropical Depression Grace, which are also moving through the region.
content: An already active day in the Atlantic hurricane season became a little busier on Monday, when Tropical Storm Henri formed off the East Coast of the United States, joining Tropical Storm Fred, which made landfall in the Florida Panhandle in the afternoon, and Tropical Depression Grace, which came ashore in Haiti, complicating search-and-rescue efforts after a powerful earthquake killed hundreds of people on Saturday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Delta fuels a new, disheartening phase.
content: Only a few weeks ago, the pandemic felt like it was slowly coming to an end for many Americans. Now, a flood of new cases fueled by the highly contagious Delta variant has forced the country to face a disheartening truth: The coronavirus is not going away anytime soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Kate Kelly
title: A Skeptical Stock Analyst Wins Big by Seeking Out Frauds
description: The activist short-seller behind Hindenburg Research has become known for research that sends companies’ stock sinking. He says he’s not in it just to move share prices.
content: Last month, federal authorities charged the founder of the electric vehicle manufacturer Nikola, which had gone public in the summer of 2020, with defrauding investors. They were led there partly by the work of a little-known Wall Streeter named Nathan Anderson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Anderson
title: A Mississippi Restaurant Has Been Beloved for Decades. But There’s Another Story to Tell.
description: Lusco’s, a century-old fixture in the Delta, became known for its food, and for Booker Wright, a Black waiter who dared to tell the truth about the Jim Crow-era South.
content: GREENWOOD, Miss. — In the Deep South, any restaurant that has operated for nearly a century is bound to have a complicated racial history. Lusco’s is one of those.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Spectators Barred From Paralympics
description: Officials cited rising coronavirus infection rates. “Everyone is encouraged to watch the Games at home,” a statement said.
content: Like the Olympics before it, the Paralympics in Tokyo will allow virtually no spectators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino, Jim Huylebroek and Kiana Hayeri
title: Kabul’s Sudden Fall to Taliban Ends U.S. Era in Afghanistan
description: A takeover of the entire country was all but absolute as the Afghan government collapsed and the U.S. rushed through a frenzied evacuation.
content: Taliban fighters poured into the Afghan capital on Sunday amid scenes of panic and chaos, bringing a swift and shocking close to the Afghan government and the 20-year American era in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: Finding a Home that Can Accommodate a Disability
description: When he found himself hobbled by a nerve problem, he knew he couldn’t stay in his walk-up. Moving to a new building near a transit hub was the solution.
content: When Jason Knebel moved to a new apartment about two months ago, he made a rare purchase for a single person moving into a studio: a second bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.7 Million Homes in California
description: An Elizabethan-style cottage in Berkeley, a ranch house in Los Angeles and a three-bedroom townhouse in Hermosa Beach.
content: This house was designed by Eldridge Theodore Spencer, a local architect, as a home and theatrical studio for Merle Marston, the daughter of a prominent Berkeley family and a teacher of dance and acting. Details in the home reflect its dual purpose: A door leading from the kitchen to the stage (now a dining area) is frameless, creating the illusion of a solid wall, and there is a passageway from a front hall closet to the bathroom to facilitate costume changes during performances. Woven into the design are hand-painted florals by Mr. Spencer’s wife, Jeanette Spencer, a painter whose murals can be seen at the Ahwahanee hotel, in Yosemite National Park, also designed by Mr. Spencer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives, Alyssa Lukpat and Neil Vigdor
title: More evacuations are ordered for thousands in the path of wildfires across the West.
description: Even as the Bootleg fire in Oregon was fully contained, residents in California, Montana and Utah had to flee their homes.
content: A township north of the Mendocino National Forest in Northern California was issued a mandatory evacuation order on Monday morning, becoming the latest in a series of communities across the west where raging wildfires have forced several thousand residents to flee their homes in recent days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: Cooking With a Dash of Science
description: For the Times food columnist J. Kenji López-Alt, the kitchen is also a lab, where an understanding of a few basics at the molecular level can make a difference in your next dish.
content: J. Kenji López-Alt, a food columnist for The New York Times, approaches home cooking like a scientist. He explains the basic elements of food like proteins and fat and examines what happens to them on a molecular level during cooking — all in the name of making the best scrambled eggs, the best burger or a perfectly light schnitzel (the secret is vodka, among other things). He is also a James Beard award-winning cookbook author with a popular YouTube channel. Here, he talks about the influences that shaped his cooking, how he views science in the context of food and what he makes at home. This interview has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Colter Walls
title: A Reliably Varied Music Festival Returns to New York
description: Time Spans, a wide-ranging immersion in contemporary work, balances good taste and risk-taking.
content: The Time Spans festival has carved out a unique place for itself in New York’s musical life over the past decade — and not just because it occupies an otherwise barren stretch of the calendar in late August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Saved by a Bucket, but Can the Owens Pupfish Survive?
description: A new refuge in the California desert offers a long imperiled species its first real chance to thrive.
content: The Owens pupfish, a small blue fish native to the springs in the California desert, was spared from extinction on an August afternoon in 1969 by Phil Pister and his two buckets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Michael Crowley
title: The Taliban takeover of Afghanistan could extinguish U.S. influence in Kabul.
description: The fall of Kabul leaves the Biden administration facing the once-unthinkable prospect of whether, and how, to engage with a Taliban-led government in Afghanistan’s capital — or cede all influence in the country to an extremist group that brutalized Afghans and harbored Osama bin Laden as he planned attacks on America.
content: The fall of Kabul leaves the Biden administration facing the once-unthinkable prospect of whether, and how, to engage with a Taliban-led government in Afghanistan’s capital — or cede all influence in the country to an extremist group that brutalized Afghans and harbored Osama bin Laden as he planned attacks on America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Taliban’s victory in Afghanistan.
content: Taliban fighters poured into Kabul amid scenes of panic and chaos yesterday, bringing a swift and shocking close to the Afghan government and the 20-year American era in the country. Afghanistan’s capital fell to the Taliban far faster than many had imagined it would, leaving most Afghans with no way out. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: The Supreme Court Blocks New York’s Eviction Moratorium
description: The court said tenants cannot self-certify that they have experienced hardship during the pandemic.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tell us what you’ve learned about self-care during the pandemic.
description: We’d love to hear from you.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has forced many of us to make lifestyle changes and reflect on our physical and mental health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Babies and Toddlers Spread Virus in Homes More Easily Than Teens, Study Finds
description: Although young children bring the coronavirus home less often than teens do, their close contact with caregivers may make them likelier to transmit it.
content: Babies and toddlers are less likely to bring the coronavirus into their homes than teenagers are, but once they are infected, they are more likely to spread the virus to others in their households, according to a large new study by a Canadian public health agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Noah Weiland
title: The prospect of booster shots is igniting a global health debate.
description: Citing a lack of scientific evidence, the W.H.O. argues that extra vaccine doses should be sent to poor countries instead.
content: As the Delta variant rages around the world, a heated debate has arisen over whether public health officials should recommend booster shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Cheesiest Art Talk
description: The Met has teamed up with Jasper Hill Farm for a virtual discussion about cheese in art, with morsels available to sample in real life.
content: Art and artifacts that feature food in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art span millenniums, from ancient Egypt to Pop Art. Narrow the search to a single foodstuff, cheese, and there is still plenty to savor, as Laura Corey, a senior researcher in the director’s office, will show in a virtual class later this month. Also on the panel will be Zoe Brickley, the creative director of Jasper Hill Farm in Vermont. And so the class is not merely digital, participants have the option to receive a selection of seven Jasper Hill cheeses from Jasper Hill to sample during the class. The deadline for ordering cheeses is Aug. 23; the class will be recorded for those who register but can’t watch it live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Walden’ Review: Getting Away From It All
description: Amy Berryman’s three-character drama, set in a one-room cabin as crises rage outside, asks how much we owe to ourselves and our world.
content: We don’t know exactly how many years into the future Amy Berryman sets “Walden,” her incisive three-character drama. But the climate emergency has already worsened, along with a refugee crisis. Synthetic foods are now widespread. Cloning, too. War rages somewhere. (Everywhere?)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Dana Rubinstein
title: As Cuomo Exits, Will Congestion Pricing Still Come to New York City?
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo leaves behind unfinished transportation projects, including a plan to charge fees to drive in Manhattan.
content: New York City’s aging subway system was supposed to receive hundreds of millions of dollars for upgrades this year — a windfall that had been badly needed even before the coronavirus pandemic decimated the system’s ridership and finances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Andre Paultre
title: Haiti Quake Destroyed Many Churches, Shredding a Mainstay of Support
description: “We are the only thing here,” said a cleric in Les Cayes, one of the cities worst hit by the quake. In some towns, not a church was left standing.
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The houses collapsed, the hospitals were damaged, the roads buckled or turned impassable. But it was the earthquake’s destruction of churches across Haiti’s southern peninsula that may prove the biggest gut punch to the roughly 1.5 million people affected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Breanna Stewart’s Golden Journey to Motherhood
description: “I went from one emotion to the next,” the W.N.B.A. star said. “From winning a gold medal to realizing, OK, I’m going home, and my daughter is going to be born in less than 24 hours.”
content: Breanna Stewart is ready to tell her secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
title: Delta Surge Drives Home Painful Truth: Covid Isn’t Going Away
description: The new flood of cases has forced Americans to recalibrate. Governors and mayors who imposed shutdowns last summer are pushing vaccines now.
content: CHICAGO — As alarm mounted over the coronavirus ripping through the country, Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago was barraged with warnings: Lollapalooza was looking increasingly risky. The annual four-day music festival would draw hundreds of thousands of people downtown, unmasked, crowded into mosh pits, city parks, restaurants and L trains, setting up the threat of a superspreader coronavirus event in the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Joseph Gordon-Levitt: ‘Silicon Valley Now Owns Hollywood’
description: The actor, who’s set to play the controversial Uber co-founder Travis Kalanick in an upcoming series, thinks the tech takeover may be a good thing.
content: Joseph Gordon-Levitt is deep in Silicon Valley these days. No, he’s not pitching a start-up (though he does have one of those): He is playing Uber’s former chief executive Travis Kalanick in an upcoming Showtime anthology series. And while Gordon-Levitt has some thoughts about society’s “deification of technology,” he is relatively bullish on Silicon Valley and the trend of tech companies taking over Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
title: Japan’s Economy Returns to Growth, but Virus Threat Looms
description: Even as other major economies have roared back to life, Japan’s has been stuck in a cycle of growth and contraction.
content: TOKYO — Japan stepped back into economic growth in the second three months of 2021, but prospects for a more robust recovery looked dim as the country grappled with its worst coronavirus outbreak since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amber Pinkerton and Nell Kalonji
title: This Fall, Leather Meets Bright, Body-Con Pieces
description: Together, these luscious separates and candy-colored accents make for an appealing balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Minimum Wage Can Create Jobs
description: A new way to think about this oddity of the labor market.
content: This is a preview of the Peter Coy newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox three times a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger
title: Biden stands behind Afghan withdrawal, despite ‘hard and messy’ final days.
description: The president said U.S. troops should not be fighting a war Afghan forces are not willing to fight. Afghanistan’s leaders and military had been given every chance to determine their future, he said.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden offered a defiant defense on Monday of his decision to withdraw troops from Afghanistan, blaming the swift collapse of the Afghan government and chaotic scenes at the Kabul airport on the refusal of the country’s military to stand and fight in the face of the Taliban advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Afghanistan, Haiti, Virus: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: School Is Starting. Can Children Stay Safe From Covid-19?
description: How to limit infections in the classroom. Plus, what the data shows about how the Delta variant affects children.
content: This wasn’t how the school year was supposed to begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: The Fallout from Afghanistan
description: The economic and political effects of the Taliban takeover will be felt around the world.
content: The 20-year American era in Afghanistan came to a swift, shocking close yesterday as the Taliban seized the capital, Kabul. Afghanistan’s president fled the country, and a council of Afghan officials pledged to negotiate with the insurgents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Can the vaccinated develop long Covid?
description: Long Covid remains a worrisome complication after a Covid-19 infection. Are the vaccinated at risk, too?
content: Despite concerns about the Delta variant and breakthrough coronavirus cases, it’s clear that the vaccines are protecting us from hospitalization and death. Typically, breakthrough infections result in mild to moderate symptoms or no symptoms at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Saturn’s Rings Are Like a Seismometer That Reveal the Planet’s Core
description: Convulsions in the planet’s interior are picked up in the region known as the C ring, and help scientists understand what lies within.
content: Saturn’s icy rings are not just aesthetically wondrous marvels. One of them also records a beautiful planetary soundtrack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Gordon
title: By Maurice Carlos Ruffin, Stories of a New Orleans That’s All but Lost
description: In “The Ones Who Don’t Say They Love You,” the city’s Black residents try to hold onto what the hurricanes and gentrifiers haven’t taken yet.
content: THE ONES WHO DON’T SAY THEY LOVE YOU Stories By Maurice Carlos Ruffin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder and Joana França
title: A Home That Retreats Into the Brazilian Savanna
description: Informed by the utopian architecture of Brasília, an expansive weekend house honors and melds with the vanishing landscape of the Cerrado.
content: AS A CHILD in the young city of Brasília, a futuristic capital conjured out of Brazil’s vast interior savannas in the late ’50s, Ilka Teodoro, now 43, would spend weekends on her grandfather’s farm 25 miles northeast of the city. The farm was on a 48-acre property dominated by the low shrubs and contorted trees native to the country’s second-largest biome, the Cerrado, which covers more than 772,000 square miles, nearly a quarter of Brazil. Now the center of a protected ecological area called Águas Emendadas, her family’s plot included rows of fruiting plants and a foundry for adobe bricks. Around them was wilderness, a dry, slow-growing landscape dominated by grasses, brush and gnarled flowering trees that few people — Brazilians included — associate with a country known for its rainforests and beaches.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Lox, Triumphant at Verzuz
description: A conversation about New York hip-hop in the 1990s and early 2000s, and a night that brought the spirit of battle back to the pandemic-era staple.
content: In early August, Verzuz — the pandemic-era staple that began on Instagram Live and within a year morphed into a multi-platform content powerhouse with artists “battling” hit for hit — held its first live, ticketed, in-person event. The night featured two of New York’s most historically vital hip-hop crews, the Lox and Dipset, facing off at the Hulu Theater at Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: U.S. Veterans View Afghan Collapse With Anguish, Rage and Relief
description: “I just can’t help thinking about what a waste it is,” one veteran said. “I can’t allow myself to think about how after all that blood and treasure, it ends like this.”
content: On Javier Mackey’s second deployment to Afghanistan, one of his friends was shot in an ambush and bled to death in his arms. He saw high-ranking Afghan officers selling off equipment for personal gain and Afghan troops running away during firefights. And he started wondering what the United States could really achieve by sending thousands of troops to a distant land that seemed to have never known peace. That was in 2008.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall, Daniel Victor and Ruhullah Khapalwak
title: The Taliban take over the presidential palace.
description: After a peaceful overtaking of the palace in Kabul, the insurgents said they would use the building to announce the restoration of an Islamic emirate.
content: The sight of gun-toting Taliban fighters behind President Ashraf Ghani’s ornate wooden desk, deep inside the Afghan presidential palace now under their control, served as visual confirmation that power in the country had fully shifted hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang, Isabella Kwai and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Australia’s worsening outbreak raises concerns about Aboriginal communities.
description: With the Delta variant spreading, only 15 percent of Indigenous people over the age of 16 have been fully inoculated, well behind the national level, according to officials.
content: As the Delta variant of the coronavirus spreads beyond Sydney into the surrounding state of New South Wales, concern is mounting about the potential impact on vulnerable, unvaccinated Aboriginal Australians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William D. Cohan
title: My Years on Wall Street Showed Me Why You Can’t Make a Deal on Zoom
description: Even as the Delta variant surges, it’s imperative that the finance industry get back into the office.
content: For all the endless bravado and gobs of money sloshing through Wall Street, at their core, banking and trading are apprenticeship businesses. They are akin to the Florentine guilds of the Renaissance, in which the subtleties and intricacies of art and science were absorbed over many years through careful observation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Can the Vaccinated Develop Long Covid After a Breakthrough Infection?
description: While the vaccines are effective at preventing serious illness and death, the risk of developing post-Covid health problems after a breakthrough infection isn’t known.
content: While some breakthrough cases among those who are fully vaccinated against Covid-19 are inevitable, they are unlikely to result in hospitalization or death. But one important question about breakthrough infection that remains unanswered is: Can the vaccinated develop so-called long Covid?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: A Storm Soaks Austin and the Texas Corridors of Power
description: Gov. Greg Abbott on Sunday declared an “all hands on deck” response to the flooding inside the State Capitol.
content: Driving rain that soaked Austin, Texas, and gave rise to flash flood warnings on Sunday also left the corridors of power inside the State Capitol looking like a tributary of the Colorado River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fredrik Logevall
title: How America Lost Its Way in Afghanistan
description: Two new books, “The American War in Afghanistan,” by Carter Malkasian, and “The Afghanistan Papers,” by Craig Whitlock, trace Washington’s long history of mistakes and miscalculations.
content: THE AMERICAN WAR IN AFGHANISTAN
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Malaysia’s prime minister resigns over anger about his handling of the virus.
description: Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin will stay on until a successor is appointed, continuing to steer the Southeast Asian country through its worst wave of the virus yet.
content: Battered by public anger over the Malaysian government’s handling of the coronavirus and acknowledging he had lost the support of lawmakers, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin and his entire cabinet resigned on Monday, signaling an end to a tumultuous 17-month reign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: A Mirrored Mecca for K-Pop Moves
description: An empty building in a Paris business district has become a hub for young dancers to practice and record their routines for social media.
content: PARIS — On a recent Saturday morning, Carla Kang, Audrey Kouamelan and Emma Letouche assembled in front of a squat glass building called CB3. It stands about 250 yards from the Grande Arche, the architectural marvel that is the signature structure of La Défense, a district of soaring office towers northwest of Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Food stamp aid will rise a record amount.
description: All 42 million Americans who receive food stamps will soon see their benefits rise, the largest permanent increase in the program’s history, the Biden administration plans to announce on Monday.
content: All 42 million Americans who receive food stamps will soon see their benefits rise, the largest permanent increase in the program’s history, the Biden administration plans to announce on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather and Andrew Das
title: Carli Lloyd Will Retire From U.S. Women’s Soccer Team
description: Lloyd, one of her sport’s most decorated players, said she would finish her club season and then play four farewell matches with the United States.
content: Carli Lloyd, a former world player of the year who was one of the United States women’s national team’s career leaders in goals, games and honors, announced her retirement from soccer at age 39 on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Scrambling to evacuate Afghanistan.
content: President Biden insisted in an address from the White House that the U.S. mission in Afghanistan “was never supposed to be about nation-building,” and said there was no easy time to withdraw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Everyone Will Breathe This Polluted Air One Day
description: The defeat of the Byhalia Connection pipeline was a rare victory against environmental racism.
content: NASHVILLE — Something wonderful happened in Memphis last month: Community organizers in the city managed to stop a crude-oil pipeline from running beneath the historic neighborhood of Boxtown, as well as several other predominantly Black communities along its projected 45-mile route.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Baker
title: Patagonia, Adorned in Autumn
description: Southern Chile’s snow-capped mountains, vast plains and windswept lakes are often depicted in summertime. See the landscape dressed in autumnal hues.
content: I was awakened in the predawn hours by a raging downpour. Cold, howling winds were coming off the lake, and the screen door to our half-domed shelter was flapping violently. Huddled with a few other hikers, I quickly realized the value of our lodging’s design: It’s one of the few structures that can withstand the extreme weather conditions that are a common occurrence in Patagonia. Thankfully, all of us — along with my camera gear — were safe and dry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, Karen Yourish, Lauren Leatherby and Sarah Kerr
title: Chaos and Desperation at the Kabul Airport
description: Maps and satellite images of the airport show the chaos as people race to leave Afghanistan.
content: Maps and satellite images of the airport show the chaos as people race to leave Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman
title: You May Have to Show Proof of Vaccination in N.Y.C. Starting Tomorrow. Here's How.
description: As of Aug. 17, indoor dining, fitness and entertainment venues must check for vaccination status.
content: As of Aug. 17, indoor dining, fitness and entertainment venues must check for vaccination status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Get Ready to Pay More for Your Morning Joe
description: Climate shocks in Brazil and shipping bottlenecks have pushed the price of coffee beans higher — and farmers and roasters are feeling the effects.
content: Climate shocks in Brazil and shipping bottlenecks have pushed the price of coffee beans higher — and farmers and roasters are feeling the effects.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.7 Million in California
description: An Elizabethan-style cottage in Berkeley, a ranch house in Los Angeles and a three-bedroom townhouse in Hermosa Beach.
content: An Elizabethan-style cottage in Berkeley, a ranch house in Los Angeles and a three-bedroom townhouse in Hermosa Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taliban Seize Afghanistan
description: Taliban Seize Afghanistan
content: Taliban Seize Afghanistan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. Allies Flee Afghanistan on Iconic Friendship Bridge
description: Pro-government soldiers crossed the Friendship Bridge in order to find safety in Uzbekistan. The scene was similar to an iconic moment when the Soviet Army used the bridge to escape after it was defeated.
content: Pro-government soldiers crossed the Friendship Bridge in order to find safety in Uzbekistan. The scene was similar to an iconic moment when the Soviet Army used the bridge to escape after it was defeated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Blackstone and Taylor Turner
title: Watch: Scenes of Panic and Chaos at Kabul Airport
description: One day after the Taliban seized control of Afghanistan, thousands of people who were desperate to flee the country rushed to the airport in Kabul.
content: One day after the Taliban seized control of Afghanistan, thousands of people who were desperate to flee the country rushed to the airport in Kabul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Defends U.S. Withdrawal from Afghanistan
description: President Biden said he stood “squarely behind” the decision to withdraw U.S. forces from Afghanistan despite a Taliban takeover of the country, and the collapse of the Afghan government and military.
content: President Biden said he stood “squarely behind” the decision to withdraw U.S. forces from Afghanistan despite a Taliban takeover of the country, and the collapse of the Afghan government and military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Wildfires Force Evacuations Across the West
description: Residents in states across the Western U.S. have been forced to evacuate their homes as intense heat and drought have fueled a devastating wildfire season.
content: Residents in states across the Western U.S. have been forced to evacuate their homes as intense heat and drought have fueled a devastating wildfire season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Fishing for Tuna Poke
description: Use Atlantic bonito for a Northeastern spin on the Hawaiian classic.
content: Good morning. The shorebirds that passed me on their way north after the winter are starting to push south along the coast of New England and New York, which means the fall run is starting and not just for birds. We’ll see striped bass heading south pretty soon as well, along with false albacore and bluefish. If we’re lucky — if I’m lucky, out on a boat somewhere where there’s current and bait — there’ll be Atlantic bonito at some point, too, feeding on spearing and, hopefully, one of my badly tied flies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The U.S. in Afghanistan: A Mess With ‘No Good Outcomes’
description: Readers discuss whether the U.S. mishandled the withdrawal, the Taliban’s quick takeover and the country’s future.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
